Award.AwardTitle: Control of lipid metabolism and muscle hypertrophy by PPARs in Gray catbird annual life cycle
Award.AbstractNarration: Migratory birds are among nature's most accomplished athletes. Many of these birds undertake journeys of several thousand miles with little rest. In addition to the challenges of timing and navigation, the energy costs of migration are very high. Migrating birds operate at a level of effort that may be double that of a Tour de France bicycle racer. As these birds often do not stop to refuel, in the weeks before departure birds become obsessed with feeding and gain weight rapidly. Added fat stores may be 50% of their body weight, equivalent to a 150 pound human gaining 75 pounds in less than a month. Equally astonishing, flight muscle size increases in preparation for migration, even in birds kept inactive in captivity. In both cases, there is a resetting of normal anatomy (structure) and physiology (function) of these animals to match the requirements of migration. While much is known about these dramatic shifts, little is known about how they are controlled. Control of preparation for migration may lie with a family of gene regulators called peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors or PPARs, regulatory proteins found in all vertebrates. In mammals, where they have been most studied, PPARs control both the storage of fats in adipose tissue as well as the use of fats as fuel in muscle. Drugs that modulate their activity are in development for treatment of human metabolic disorders. By manipulating PPAR activity using these drugs, researchers will explore the roles of PPARs in migration. As migration may be one of the most profound challenges to energy demands in any animal, researchers will unveil details of metabolism and its regulation while shedding light on one of nature's marvels. Additionally, the PPARs normally respond to dietary signals, thus birds may be choosing foods that help to spur necessary changes. The researchers will work with local school children to explore the needs of migrating birds for native plants and develop curricula that brings habitat and migration together while teaching about avian diversity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flying across vast landscapes, migrating birds are capable of one of nature’s most amazing athletic feats. To support this endeavor, birds remodel their bodies in impressive ways. Prior to departure, they may add 50% of their body weight in fat tissue to store fuel for the journey. Without exercise training, they increase flight muscle size and the ability to use fats for fuel. Work in mammals has found that a group of cell receptors (called the PPARs) regulate tissue fat metabolism. These receptors can be activated by dietary or internally synthesized fats and act to increase fat storage in adipose tissue or to increase the ability to burn fats in working muscle (including the heart). We found that the PPARs do indeed exist in these birds and have very similar expression patterns in muscles and adipose of both birds and mammals. We investigated the potential for these PPARs to regulate the transitions observed in a migrating bird species, the gray catbird. We measured changes in metabolism in liver, adipose and flight muscles in birds at five life stages: summer breeding, pre-migration, fall migration, overwintering, and spring migration. The spring-to-fall migration stages were studied in birds captured in Ohio; whereas the tropical overwintering birds were studied at a field site in Belize. 

We found that the PPARs are activated seasonally and increase fat metabolic pathways in adipose and muscle, but that they are clearly not acting alone as many critical elements of the pathways are not affected by changing PPAR activity. We found that altering light cycles strongly stimulates the fat storage aspects of migratory preparation, acting either in parallel or upstream of PPARs, but that the ability to burn fat is inhibited if only light signals are present. We conclude that PPARs are important players in avian fat metabolism and in migration, but that their interaction with other factors is also critical.

To understand how these receptors work at a molecular level we isolated the specific regions of the catbird genome that express each of the PPARs. To our knowledge this is the first molecular analysis of PPARs conducted in a migratory bird species. We found that they have remarkably similar structure and function in birds and mammals. In studies performed in cells we found that the catbird PPARs are directly activated by lipids found in the avian diet at increased levels prior to migration. Interestingly, synthetic drugs that target PPARs and are used to treat diabetes and to lower lipid levels in patients showed similar activity with the catbird receptors. Moreover, simply expressing more PPAR protein in muscle cells was sufficient to increase the amount and activity of enzymes involved in fat metabolism. The results of these comparative studies show that the function of catbird PPARs closely mimics that of the mammalian receptors. Our findings provide a basis for future studies to understand the similarities and differences between migratory fattening in birds, which is an adaptive strategy, and obesity in humans, which is associated with a multitude of diseases based in metabolism, including heart disease and diabetes.
